alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Estancia Valley; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Middle Rio Grande Valley, Albuquerque Metro Area; San Agustin Plains and Adjacent Lowlands; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Santa Fe Metro Area; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southwest Mountains; West Central Highlands (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 06 at 2:56PM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...WINTER WEATHER IMPACTS TUESDAY MORNING COMMUTE FOR CENTRAL NM... Winter weather in the form of snow and gusty winds will reach much of central NM stretching from the southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains southward through the east mountain communities and central highlands to the south-central mountains. This will also stretch westward into portions of the Santa Fe and Albuquerque metro areas and over to Grants and the Continental Divide. Snow accumulations will range from a dusting to 1 inch at most lower elevation areas, to 1 to 3 inches in the foothills, to as high as 3 to 6 inches above 9,000 feet. Potential travel impacts from snow accumulations will focus along I-40 in the east mountain communities and east slopes of the Sandia/Manzano Mountains, U.S. Highway 60 west of Socorro, and NM Highways 169 north of Magdalena. Potential snow accumulations in the Albuquerque metro area will be variable, ranging from near zero immediately down from Tijeras Canyon where strong east canyon winds will blow snow away, to a half inch in the northeast heights, to 1 to 2 inches along the west mesa and Rio Rancho. Snow will begin after midnight, peaking through the morning hours, and slowly tapering off through the afternoon as the main storm system moves east toward Texas. Allow extra time to reach your destinations during the morning commute or delay travel if possible.
